>So said Mike Clark on 2003-06-10 --------------------
>Dave Astels wrote:=

>> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:=

>> 
>>>>So said hehaifengcn on 2003-06-10 --------------------
>>>>I have =
a project in which I want to some tools that can 
>>>>automatically generat=
e test case to exercise given execution path.
>>>
>> 
>>>The idea of automa=
tically generating tests is incompatible with the 
>>>JUnit (and xUnit) phi=
losophy. JUnit is a framework in which humans 
>>>write tests; it is not a =
tool that writes tests.
>> 
>> 
>> Well said.  I'll go farther and say that=
 even a tool that generates a
>> set of JUnit (or xUnit) stubs to test all =
(or some selected subset) 
>> the methods of a given class is incompatible =
with the philosophy. 
>> JUnit is used to test behaviour.  Behaviours and m=
ethods and not 1-1
>> or onto.  A single behavior may encompass functionall=
ity from several
>> methods, and a single method may embody several behavio=
urs.  Hmm..
>> there's an article in there.
>> 
>> 
>
>That being said, whe=
n I'm trying to add new functionality to legacy code 
>that doesn't have te=
sts, I'll gain confidence in any way possible.  If I 
>can easily run a too=
l that generates some amount of tests, then I'll use 
>those tests as anoth=
er anchor point.  That is, I'll sic the tool on the 
>existing code base, t=
hen continually run the tests it generates as I'm 
>retrofitting the code. =
 Better than nothin'.

This is a fine point. Look at the kinds of "tests" t=
hat JTest can generate: simple boundary cases and unexpected exceptions. Wh=
en we write code -- since we are great programmers -- we don't screw up in =
such elementary ways; however, legacy code could have been written by *anyo=
ne*, so we might want to check such nonsense as NullPointerExceptions and d=
ividing by 0. Those idiots could screw up in ways we couldn't imagine.

Bey=
ond that, though, I'd rather write the tests myself. My boss may not like i=
t, but the more I learn, the better I am at fixing the system.

>When I'm w=
riting new code for a system built test first, I want to write 
>all the te=
sts by hand.  In this case, tools actually impede the way I 
>learn through=
 testing.

I feel this whether it's a new or old system.

Take care.


J. B=
